body:
Hello @sandhyasun 

I have a general comment though I am not an expert in this area.  The core happened deep in the Trafodion SQL engine with the stack trace as below

#4  0x00007f281c2da322 in JVM_handle_linux_signal () from /usr/lib/jvm/java-1.7.0-openjdk.x86_64/jre/lib/amd64/server/libjvm.so
#5  <signal handler called>
#6  0x00007f281a553740 in memcpy () from /lib64/libc.so.6
#7  0x00007f281c11244a in ?? () from /usr/lib/jvm/java-1.7.0-openjdk.x86_64/jre/lib/amd64/server/libjvm.so
#8  0x00007f281b8e1df8 in hdfsWrite () from /usr/lib64/libhdfs.so.0.0.0
#9  0x00007f2817d2a6ea in ExLob::writeData (this=0x3167240, offset=<value optimized out>, data=0x1 <Address 0x1 out of bounds>, size=50, operLen=@0x7ffd7c82ee60) at ../exp/ExpLOBaccess.cpp:321
#10 0x00007f2817d2c37e in ExLob::writeLobData (this=0x3167240, source=0x1 <Address 0x1 out of bounds>, sourceLen=<value optimized out>, subOperation=Lob_Buffer, tgtOffset=<value optimized out>, operLen=@0x7ffd7c82ee60, lobMaxChunkMemSize=512) at ../exp/ExpLOBaccess.cpp:924
#11 0x00007f2817d2cf73 in ExLob::append (this=0x3167240, data=0x7ffd7c82f840 "\001", size=<value optimized out>, so=Lob_Buffer, headDescNum=<value optimized out>, operLen=@0x7ffd7c82ee60, lobMaxSize=10000, lobMaxChunkMemSize=512, lobGCLimit=5000, handleIn=0x7f280898397c "", handleInLen=68, handleOut=0x7ffd7c82f410 "H\240\210\b\216", handleOutLen=@0x7ffd7c82f850, lobGlobals=0x2a00260) at ../exp/ExpLOBaccess.cpp:1140
#12 0x00007f2817d3275a in ExLobsOper (lobName=0x7f280898517e "LOBP_04746349383199723529_0001", handleIn=0x7f280898397c "", handleInLen=68, hdfsServer=0x7ffd7c82ec80 "\230w\346\002", hdfsPort=<value optimized out>, handleOut=0x7ffd7c82f410 "H\240\210\b\216", handleOutLen=@0x7ffd7c82f850, descNumIn=4746349383880024291, descNumOut=@0x7ffd7c82ee58, retOperLen=@0x7ffd7c82ee60, requestTagIn=0, requestTagOut=@0x7ffd7c82ee58, requestStatus=@0x7ffd7c82ee6c, cliError=@0x7ffd7c82ee50, lobStorageLocation=0x7f28089855b0 "/lobs", storage=Lob_HDFS_File, source=0x7ffd7c82f840 "\001", sourceLen=50, cursorBytes=0, cursorId=0x0, operation=Lob_Append, subOperation=Lob_Buffer, waited=1, globPtr=@0x7ffd7c82ee48, transId=0, blackBox=0x0, blackBoxLen=0, lobMaxSize=10000, lobMaxChunkMemSize=512, lobGCLimit=5000, bufferSize=0, replication=0, blockS

If the testware change takes care of this core, then Trafodion SQL engine code needs to guard itself from dumping core even when there is a problem with testware.

It is possible that I misunderstood the whole issue here.
This PR is merged by squash commit to master
jenkins, retest -- automation tweak to distinguish bash installer package from pyinstaller package
Yes the testware change didn't  fix it. Looking into it further. The test passes on multiple runs on other workstations.  Will see why.
The test that was coring executor/TEST130 now passes on Jenkins too with the latest changes.
That explains the issue. Looks good

Can one of the admins verify this patch?
Can one of the admins verify this patch?
Can one of the admins verify this patch?
Can one of the admins verify this patch?

It is a nice change and it captures the stack trace when the internal assert routines are called.  There are instances when the internal asserts are ignored at the higher layer of trafodion stack while it is being transformed into an SQL error. This change would capture those instances too.

I believe compiler uses the assert mechanism to ignore invalid plans or strange conditions at the time of compiling the SQL query. Are we ignoring such cases here too to avoid false concerns about the logged assertions.

Is the executor assert reporting the stack trace already? I couldn't decipher where is it being enabled now

Why is this feature going into the release2.0 branch instead of the master branch?

Also, what JIRA is associated with this work?
@sandhyasun, would you please review this change? Thanks.
TRAFODION-2413 tracks the second fix (row length of aligned format tables)

General comment before reviewing any more changes. The LOBGlobals class is instantiated from the ex_globals constructor. The heap_ stored in LOBGlobals is derived from the executor heap. In ExLOB::Initialize, we get the lobGlobalHeap_ from the LOBGlobals->heap_ pointer. So the lobGlobalsHeap_ is not an STL heap.  Hence replacing the "new" from lobGlobalHeap_ with STL calls isn't really correct.
Actually, it's not that big a deal. I will change string stack variables to NAStrings and resubmit.

@sandhyasun, I made an attempt at making these NAStrings instead of strings. It gets ugly pretty fast. I think it better to change these stack variables to NAStrings when the corresponding members change also. So, I'd prefer to leave them as strings, unless I've missed something in your objection.

Some classes like ExLobCursors are derived from the standard heap. My comment above was that for any class like ExLob that is derived from the executor heap,  we shoudl try to keep all the datamembers also allocated on that heap rather than have them on the system heap.

General comment: It is good to have any local variables within the executor portion of the code unless we are sure it is allocated from the stack entirely.  Rationale: If the scope of the variable is at a statement level,  and allocated from the statement heap, it will be automatically deallocated when the statement heap is de-allocated. If any variable is allocated from system heap, it increases the possibility of creating fragmented memory though you have correctly deallocated the variable in question, Some other part of the code might have had some memory leaks from system heap and that caused the block of the memory to be left behind. This bloats the virtual memory of the process.

Please do not merge. I'm doing reworks to address three issues raised by @sandhyasun and @selvaganesang:

1. Changing ExLob to be allocated off the Lob Heap (and making its lobDataFile_ member an NAString instead of a string)
2. Changing the handling of stack variables to avoid global heap allocations
3. Addressing the potential issue with the black box buffer passed to the CLI
